) Audience. This IRM section is designed for use by Specialty Collection vency (SCI) caseworkers and management in the Centralized Insolvency Operation (CIO) and Field Insolvency (FI). This IRM section may be by other operations when dealing with a taxpayer that has ﬁled Chapter

) Policy Owner. The Director of Collection Policy is responsible for issuing policy for the Insolvency program. (
) Program Owner. The program owner is Collection Policy, Insolvency, an nization within the Small Business / Self-Employed (SB/SE) division. (
) Primary Stakeholders. The primary stakeholder is SB/SE Collection, Collection Insolvency. (
) Program Goals. The goal of this IRM is to provide fundamental knowledge and procedural guidance for working Chapter

cases, facilitating effective monitoring and timely closure actions on behalf of the government’s interest while ensuring taxpayer rights are protected. Following the guidance in this IRM will ensure cases are worked in accordance with bankruptcy laws and regulations. (
) Reorganization of Debts for Individuals. A Chapter

bankruptcy repre- sents a voluntary reorganization of debts for individuals. The debtors, who usually retain all of their assets, commit a portion of their future income to repay creditors. Cases normally remain open for

) Chapter
Trustee Contact. A court-appointed trustee oversees the tration of a Chapter
bankruptcy case. Generally, FI caseworkers make direct contact with trustees. Limited contact between CIO and the trustee be necessary, usually to resolve payment posting issues. (
) Trustee Duties. The Chapter

trustee: a. Acts as an agent of the court. b. Oversees the fair and economical administration of cases. c. Ensures all creditors receive an equitable distribution. d. Receives periodic payments from the debtor. e. Distributes periodic payments to creditors. (
) Protection of the Government’s Interests. Sometimes, the interests of creditors compete with the interests of the IRS. Because conﬁrmation take place early in Chapter
cases, Insolvency must address case issues Internal Revenue Manual

Program Owner. The program owner is Collection Policy, Insolvency, an orga- nization within the Small Business / Self-Employed (SB/SE) division.

Reorganization of Debts for Individuals. A Chapter 13 bankruptcy repre- sents a voluntary reorganization of debts for individuals. The debtors, who usually retain all of their assets, commit a portion of their future income to repay creditors. Cases normally remain open for 36 to 60 months, with 60 months being the maximum and most common time frame. Under the provi- sions of the Bankruptcy Abuse Prevention and Consumer Protection Act of 2005 (BAPCPA), for bankruptcies commencing on or after October 17, the plan length is determined by the relationship of the debtor’s income to median income in the state where the debtor ﬁled the bankruptcy petition USC 1322(d)). This chapter is not available to corporations, Limited Liability Companies (LLCs), or partnerships. Chapter 13 is available only to

) Centralized Insolvency Operation (CIO). CIO loads Chapter
cases onto the Automated Insolvency System (AIS), runs the Insolvency Interface (IIP), and works any errors, including the Potentially Invalid TIN (PIT) list. works all Chapter
status reports. CIO monitors Chapter
cases for mation of the plan after the case is transferred from FI to CIO, and Chapter
trustee payments. Upon closure of a Chapter
case by the ruptcy court, CIO makes any necessary account adjustments and closes the case on AIS. CIO handles the toll-free and internal phones for most Chapter
bankruptcy case inquiries. (
) Field Insolvency (FI). FI completes the initial case review in Chapter

and ensures that any required proofs of claim are completed and acknowl- edged. If there are no ﬁeld issues, the case is generally transferred to CIO to monitor for conﬁrmation. FI caseworkers review schedules and plans in Chapter
cases, make referrals to Counsel, attend ﬁrst meetings of participate in outreach efforts, and negotiate with debtors or their representa- tives. FI handles calls received on Chapter
cases currently assigned to a group and on complex Chapter
cases. (

) Pre-Bankruptcy Collection Actions. Activity in other Service functions may be pending or ongoing when the bankruptcy is ﬁled (for example, a revenue officer may have outstanding levies). Coordination between Insolvency and functions taking collection or examination action helps the IRS comply with provisions of the automatic stay. • The Service must protect taxpayer rights by avoiding actions in of the automatic stay. • If a violation of the stay occurs, the IRS may be liable for damages attorney’s fees, but not punitive damages. ) Discharge Limitations. In Chapter

cases, debtors may not be eligible to receive a discharge in the current bankruptcy case when they received a discharge in a prior bankruptcy case. Courts have held that eligibility for discharge depends on the petition date of the prior bankruptcy case and the petition date of the current bankruptcy case, as well as the type of prior ruptcy case ﬁled by the debtor. ) CSED Protection. Per IRC

(h), the running of the statutory period for lection, known as the Collection Statute Expiration Date (CSED), is and collection is prohibited while the debtor is in bankruptcy, plus six months after. This suspension only applies to the debtor. If only one spouse ﬁles ruptcy but joint income tax returns were ﬁled, the caseworker is required to review the CSED and address any imminent CSED’s. See IRM
, CSED, for additional information. (
) Exam Issues. IRM
, Examination and Insolvency, provides guidance addressing examination issues. A review of AMDISA and contact with the revenue agent or examiner may be required. (

) TFRP Issues. A review of the bankruptcy schedules or SOFA may reveal the debtor is an officer of a corporation, a member of a LLC, or a partner in partnership. If the corporation, LLC, or partnership has unpaid withholding or excise taxes, the Chapter

debtor may be responsible for the Trust Fund Recovery Penalty (TFRP). A review of the Automated Trust Fund Recovery (ATFR) program is necessary to determine what periods may have a TFRP proposed but not yet assessed against the debtor. These unassessed must be added manually to the proof of claim. Information on parties that be assessed a TFRP can be found in: • IRM
, Establishing Responsibility • IRM

Additional Aspects. Facts and circumstances in the case may warrant addi- tional research, especially in the “large dollar” Chapter
case. Additional research that may be necessary include:
A review of prior AIS histories when AIS identiﬁed prior bankruptcy ﬁlings. A review and analysis of locator services, such as Accurint.

) Unﬁled Returns. Effective October
, no later than the day before the

meeting is ﬁrst scheduled, the debtor must ﬁle all tax returns “with the propriate tax authorities” that are due under applicable non-bankruptcy law for taxable periods ending during the four year period prior to, or on, the date of the ﬁling of the bankruptcy petition (
USC
(a)). After FI has made a sonable attempt to resolve the non-compliance administratively, if tax returns remain unﬁled by the

) Acceptance of Deﬁcient Plans. If a debtor demonstrates that it is in the ernment’s best interest to accept less favorable treatment than is required under the Bankruptcy Code, the speciﬁc payment terms must be into the debtor’s plan. The debtor will comply with all ﬁling, withholding, and estimated tax payment requirements during the life of the plan; and c. The Government’s right to collect upon a default in plan payments. General Information. A debtor may ﬁle Chapter
bankruptcy and owe a liability for a criminal restitution assessment. Chapter
cases with criminal restitution assessments are generally treated in the same manner as Chapter
cases with criminal restitution assessments. For general information on criminal restitution assessments, see IRM

, Working Criminal Restitution Cases. All cases with criminal restitution assessments are classiﬁed and assigned in the same manner.

plan is or modiﬁed, the court enters an order approving the modiﬁcation or amendment. The modiﬁcation does not change the original conﬁrmation date. ) Impact of Bankruptcy Estate Interpretations. The legal interpretation of the “bankruptcy estate” in a given area will determine the course of action taken by the Service. (

) Conversion/Dismissal Considerations. When Insolvency determines a debtor is not adhering to the plan and the plan is not modiﬁed, Insolvency may consider referring the case to Counsel to request a motion for dismissal or conversion, particularly in cases of egregious non-compliance. No action should be taken until FI has contacted the trustee to attempt to resolve the plan problems and issues. Counsel may be consulted on an “as needed” basis before the formal referral is forwarded. The bankruptcy court is more likely to give favorable consideration to the Service’s conversion or dismissal motion if the motion is ﬁled in the early stages of the bankruptcy rather than toward the end of the plan.

) Bankruptcy Code Guidelines. Three sections of the Bankruptcy Code affecting the determination of “property of the estate” after conﬁrmation are: a.
USC
The property of the estate includes virtually all property in which the debtor has an interest at the time the petition is ﬁled, property in another’s possession and community property. b.
USC
Included in property of the estate is any property after the petition date but before the case is closed, dismissed, or converted, including both
property, wages, and other income. c.
USC
Assets revest in the debtor at conﬁrmation, unless otherwise speciﬁed in the plan or conﬁrmation order. (
) Service Position – Property of the Estate in a Chapter

Proceeding. general position of the Service is that after conﬁrmation, the bankruptcy is limited to the portion of the debtor’s income or other earnings necessary to fund the plan. a. Case law reﬂects various other positions on this issue. The two most common are the position that all of the debtor’s property remains in the estate post-conﬁrmation and the position that only property acquired post-conﬁrmation remains in the estate. b. The plan can provide that property remains in the estate. c. Counsel’s advice should be sought when clariﬁcation is required on this subject. (
) Community Property. In community property locations, property of the estate includes post-petition community property acquired by the non-debtor spouse. IRM
, Community Property, provides additional information on this topic. (

) Post-Petition Tax Liabilities. Taxes incurred after the date of the bankruptcy ﬁling are considered to be post-petition tax liabilities. The Service’s position is the accrual date, not the date of the assessment nor the date the tax was payable, determines whether a
account is considered a pre-petition or a post-petition liability. Income taxes are incurred on the last day of the taxable period, which is usually December

st of the respective tax year. Employment taxes accrue when the wages of the debtor’s employees are earned. Thus, when a debtor ﬁles bankruptcy during the middle of a quarter, and the debtor has employment tax ﬁling requirements, the taxes on wages earned prior to the petition date are pre-petition. Taxes on wages earned after the petition are post-petition.

) Application of Payments. IRM

, Payments in Bankruptcy, discusses posting of bankruptcy payments in detail. Generally, funds received from the Funds trustee are posted to AIS using the “Post Automatic Payment” option on the “Payment Monitoring Menu” on AIS. Occasionally, payments may be applied “Partially Designated”, “Semi-Automatic”, or “Manual” payments. Unless nated differently by the court, payments are systemically applied to allowed claims, by category, as follows:
Secured claims. (Each secured period is paid in full, then payment is applied to accrued interest on that module before payments are to the next oldest module.)
Priority claims. (Only the tax and interest are paid.)
Unsecured claims. (Only the tax and interest are paid.)
Penalties on priority claims.

Penalties on unsecured general claims. Note: The Service maintains its right to apply payments according to the best interests of the Government, which may not be reﬂected in the above list order of payment application. (

(e). The following are to this provision: • The order conﬁrming the plan is revoked. • The plan is in default. • The creditor has not received payments in the manner required by plan. Generally, funds received from the trustee are posted to AIS using the “Post Automatic Payment” option on the “Payment Monitoring Menu” on AIS. Occasionally, payments may be applied as “Partially Designated”, “Semi-Automatic”, or “Manual” payments. Unless desig- nated differently by the court, payments are systemically applied to allowed claims, by category, as follows:
Secured claims. (Each secured period is paid in full, then applied to accrued interest on that module before payments to the next oldest module.)
Priority claims. (Only the tax and interest are paid.)
Unsecured claims. (Only the tax and interest are paid.)
Penalties on priority claims.
Penalties on unsecured general claims.

) Setoffs and Pre-Petition Individual SRP Liabilities. Although the Code allows setoff of pre-petition income tax refunds to pre-petition income liabilities without a lifting of the stay, this does not apply to individual SRP li- abilities. Setoffs are not permitted between pre-petition SRP modules. Setoffs are not permitted between pre-petition income tax modules and pre-petition SRP liabilities. To setoff any pre-petition credit and pre-petition liability where both are not income tax requires a lifting of the stay. (

) Setoffs and Post-Petition Individual SRP Liabilities. Setoffs between post- petition income tax modules and post-petition SRP liabilities are permitted, they are not prohibited by the Bankruptcy Code. No lifting of the stay is required. (
